funcs.name: mysql_connect
funcs.desc: Opens or reuses a connection to a MySQL server.

return.desc: Returns a MySQL link identifier on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: server
args.desc:
The MySQL server. It can also include a port number. e.g. "hostname:port" or a path to a local socket e.g. ":/path/to/socket" for the localhost.

If the PHP directive mysql.default_host is undefined (default), then the default value is 'localhost:3306'. In SQL safe mode, this parameter is ignored and value 'localhost:3306' is always used.

args.name: username
args.desc: The username. Default value is defined by mysql.default_user. In SQL safe mode, this parameter is ignored and the name of the user that owns the server process is used.

args.name: password
args.desc: The password. Default value is defined by mysql.default_password. In SQL safe mode, this parameter is ignored and empty password is used.

args.name: new_link
args.desc: If a second call is made to mysql_connect() with the same arguments, no new link will be established, but instead, the link identifier of the already opened link will be returned. The new_link parameter modifies this behavior and makes mysql_connect() always open a new link, even if mysql_connect() was called before with the same parameters. In SQL safe mode, this parameter is ignored.

args.name: client_flags
args.desc: The client_flags parameter can be a combination of the following constants: 128 (enable LOAD DATA LOCAL handling), MYSQL_CLIENT_SSL, MYSQL_CLIENT_COMPRESS, MYSQL_CLIENT_IGNORE_SPACE or MYSQL_CLIENT_INTERACTIVE. Read the section about MySQL client constants for further information. In SQL safe mode, this parameter is ignored.

args.name: connect_timeout_ms
args.desc: (HipHop specific) How many milli-seconds to wait for connection.

args.name: query_timeout_ms
args.desc: (HipHop specific) How many milli-seconds to wait for query.

funcs.name: mysql_async_connect_start
funcs.desc: Initiate an asynchronous (non-blocking) connection to the specified MySQL server.

return.desc: Initiate an asynchronos mysql connect.

args.name: server
args.desc:
The MySQL server. It can also include a port number. e.g. "hostname:port" or a path to a local socket e.g. ":/path/to/socket" for the localhost.

If the PHP directive mysql.default_host is undefined (default), then the default value is 'localhost:3306'. In SQL safe mode, this parameter is ignored and value 'localhost:3306' is always used.

args.name: username
args.desc: The username. Default value is defined by mysql.default_user. In SQL safe mode, this parameter is ignored and the name of the user that owns the server process is used.

args.name: password
args.desc: The password. Default value is defined by mysql.default_password. In SQL safe mode, this parameter is ignored and empty password is used.

args.name: database
args.desc: The name of the database that will be selected.

funcs.name: mysql_async_connect_completed
funcs.desc: A nonblocking test whether a connection has completed, or errored out.

return.desc: Has the connection finished (either successfully or with error).

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection. If the link identifier is not specified, the last link opened by mysql_connect() is assumed. If no such link is found, it will try to create one as if mysql_connect() was called with no arguments. If no connection is found or established, an E_WARNING level error is generated.

funcs.name: mysql_async_query_start
funcs.desc: Initiate a nonblocking query on a given connection.

return.desc: TRUE if the query can properly be prepared and queued on the network.

args.name: query
args.desc:
An SQL query

The query string should not end with a semicolon. Data inside the query should be properly escaped.

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection. If the link identifier is not specified, the last link opened by mysql_connect() is assumed. If no such link is found, it will try to create one as if mysql_connect() was called with no arguments. If no connection is found or established, an E_WARNING level error is generated.

funcs.name: mysql_async_query_result
funcs.desc: Fetch a result object, if available, containing some rows of the nonblocking query.

return.desc: A mysql result object, or null if one isn't ready yet.

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection. If the link identifier is not specified, the last link opened by mysql_connect() is assumed. If no such link is found, it will try to create one as if mysql_connect() was called with no arguments. If no connection is found or established, an E_WARNING level error is generated.

funcs.name: mysql_async_query_completed
funcs.desc: Perform a nonblocking test whether an asynchronous query has completed.

return.desc: True if the the query has completed (i.e., either all rows have been returned or an error occurred).

args.name: result
args.desc: The mysql result object from mysql_async_query_result.

funcs.name: mysql_async_fetch_array
funcs.desc: Returns an array that corresponds to the fetched row, if available.  Nonblocking.

return.desc:
Returns an array of strings that corresponds to the fetched row, or FALSE if there are no rows currently available. The type of returned array depends on how result_type is defined. By using MYSQL_BOTH, you'll get an array with both associative and number indices. Using MYSQL_ASSOC (the default), you only get associative indices (as mysql_fetch_assoc() works), using MYSQL_NUM, you only get number indices (as mysql_fetch_row() works).

If two or more columns of the result have the same field names, the last column will take precedence. To access the other column(s) of the same name, you must use the numeric index of the column or make an alias for the column. For aliased columns, you cannot access the contents with the original column name.

args.name: result
args.desc: resource that is being evaluated. This result comes from a call to mysql_async_query_result().

args.name: result_type
args.desc: The type of array that is to be fetched. It's a constant and can take the following values: MYSQL_ASSOC, MYSQL_NUM, and MYSQL_BOTH.  The default is MYSQL_ASSOC (1)

funcs.name: mysql_async_wait_actionable
funcs.desc: Block on one or more asynchronous operations, or until the specified timeout has occurred.  Returns values from the 'items' parameter when they become actionable.  Entries are returned as soon as they are actionable (i.e., it does not wait for the entire timeout before returning results).

return.desc: Returns input entries that are now ready for action (such as a connection has completed or rows are available).

args.name: items
args.desc: An array of arrays.  These arrays contain a MySQL link identifier in the 0'th position, and any other values in the remainder of the array.  Items from this parameter are returned unmodified as the result set of actionable entries.

args.name: timeout
args.desc: Time, in seconds, to wait for actionable events.  Subsecond accuracy is supported.

funcs.name: mysql_async_status
funcs.desc: Returns the async operation status for a given mysql connection.  For non-async connections, this returns ASYNC_OP_INVALID.  For an async connection, this can be either ASYNC_OP_UNSET (no pending async operation), ASYNC_OP_QUERY (async query pending), or ASYNC_OP_CONNECT (async connection pending).  Returns -1 if the supplied connection itself is invalid.

return.desc: Returns the async operation number for this mysql connection.

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection.

funcs.name: mysql_pconnect
funcs.desc:
Establishes a persistent connection to a MySQL server.

mysql_pconnect() acts very much like mysql_connect() with two major differences.

First, when connecting, the function would first try to find a (persistent) link that's already open with the same host, username and password. If one is found, an identifier for it will be returned instead of opening a new connection.

Second, the connection to the SQL server will not be closed when the execution of the script ends. Instead, the link will remain open for future use (mysql_close() will not close links established by mysql_pconnect()).

This type of link is therefore called 'persistent'.

return.desc: Returns a MySQL persistent link identifier on success, or FALSE on failure.

args.name: server
args.desc:
The MySQL server. It can also include a port number. e.g. "hostname:port" or a path to a local socket e.g. ":/path/to/socket" for the localhost.

If the PHP directive mysql.default_host is undefined (default), then the default value is 'localhost:3306'

args.name: username
args.desc: The username. Default value is the name of the user that owns the server process.

args.name: password
args.desc: The password. Default value is an empty password.

args.name: client_flags
args.desc: The client_flags parameter can be a combination of the following constants: 128 (enable LOAD DATA LOCAL handling), MYSQL_CLIENT_SSL, MYSQL_CLIENT_COMPRESS, MYSQL_CLIENT_IGNORE_SPACE or MYSQL_CLIENT_INTERACTIVE.

args.name: connect_timeout_ms
args.desc: (HipHop specific) How many milli-seconds to wait for connection.

args.name: query_timeout_ms
args.desc: (HipHop specific) How many milli-seconds to wait for query.

funcs.name: mysql_set_charset
funcs.desc: Sets the default character set for the current connection.

return.desc: Returns TRUE on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: charset
args.desc: A valid character set name.

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection. If the link identifier is not specified, the last link opened by mysql_connect() is assumed. If no such link is found, it will try to create one as if mysql_connect() was called with no arguments. If no connection is found or established, an E_WARNING level error is generated.

funcs.name: mysql_ping
funcs.desc:
Checks whether or not the connection to the server is working. If it has gone down, an automatic reconnection is attempted. This function can be used by scripts that remain idle for a long while, to check whether or not the server has closed the connection and reconnect if necessary.

Since MySQL 5.0.13, automatic reconnection feature is disabled.

return.desc: Returns TRUE if the connection to the server MySQL server is working, otherwise FALSE.

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection. If the link identifier is not specified, the last link opened by mysql_connect() is assumed. If no such link is found, it will try to create one as if mysql_connect() was called with no arguments. If no connection is found or established, an E_WARNING level error is generated.

funcs.name: mysql_escape_string
funcs.desc:
This function will escape the unescaped_string, so that it is safe to place it in a mysql_query(). This function is deprecated.

This function is identical to mysql_real_escape_string() except that mysql_real_escape_string() takes a connection handler and escapes the string according to the current character set. mysql_escape_string() does not take a connection argument and does not respect the current charset setting. WarningThis function has been DEPRECATED as of PHP 5.3.0. Relying on this feature is highly discouraged.

return.desc: Returns the escaped string.

args.name: unescaped_string
args.desc: The string that is to be escaped.

funcs.name: mysql_real_escape_string
funcs.desc:
Escapes special characters in the unescaped_string, taking into account the current character set of the connection so that it is safe to place it in a mysql_query(). If binary data is to be inserted, this function must be used.

mysql_real_escape_string() calls MySQL's library function mysql_real_escape_string, which prepends backslashes to the following characters: \x00, \n, \r, \, ', " and \x1a.

This function must always (with few exceptions) be used to make data safe before sending a query to MySQL.

return.desc: Returns the escaped string, or FALSE on error.

args.name: unescaped_string
args.desc: The string that is to be escaped.

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection. If the link identifier is not specified, the last link opened by mysql_connect() is assumed. If no such link is found, it will try to create one as if mysql_connect() was called with no arguments. If no connection is found or established, an E_WARNING level error is generated.

funcs.name: mysql_client_encoding
funcs.desc: Retrieves the character_set variable from MySQL.

return.desc: Returns the default character set name for the current connection.

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection. If the link identifier is not specified, the last link opened by mysql_connect() is assumed. If no such link is found, it will try to create one as if mysql_connect() was called with no arguments. If no connection is found or established, an E_WARNING level error is generated.

funcs.name: mysql_close
funcs.desc:
mysql_close() closes the non-persistent connection to the MySQL server that's associated with the specified link identifier. If link_identifier isn't specified, the last opened link is used.

Using mysql_close() isn't usually necessary, as non-persistent open links are automatically closed at the end of the script's execution. See also freeing resources.

return.desc: Returns TRUE on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection. If the link identifier is not specified, the last link opened by mysql_connect() is assumed. If no such link is found, it will try to create one as if mysql_connect() was called with no arguments. If no connection is found or established, an E_WARNING level error is generated.

funcs.name: mysql_errno
funcs.desc:
Returns the error number from the last MySQL function.

Errors coming back from the MySQL database backend no longer issue warnings. Instead, use mysql_errno() to retrieve the error code. Note that this function only returns the error code from the most recently executed MySQL function (not including mysql_error() and mysql_errno()), so if you want to use it, make sure you check the value before calling another MySQL function.

return.desc: Returns the error number from the last MySQL function, or 0 (zero) if no error occurred.

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection. If the link identifier is not specified, the last link opened by mysql_connect() is assumed. If no such link is found, it will try to create one as if mysql_connect() was called with no arguments. If no connection is found or established, an E_WARNING level error is generated.

funcs.name: mysql_error
funcs.desc: Returns the error text from the last MySQL function. Errors coming back from the MySQL database backend no longer issue warnings. Instead, use mysql_error() to retrieve the error text. Note that this function only returns the error text from the most recently executed MySQL function (not including mysql_error() and mysql_errno()), so if you want to use it, make sure you check the value before calling another MySQL function.

return.desc: Returns the error text from the last MySQL function, or '' (empty string) if no error occurred.

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection. If the link identifier is not specified, the last link opened by mysql_connect() is assumed. If no such link is found, it will try to create one as if mysql_connect() was called with no arguments. If no connection is found or established, an E_WARNING level error is generated.

funcs.name: mysql_warning_count
funcs.desc: Returns the number of errors generated during execution of the previous SQL statement. To retrieve warning messages you can use the SQL command SHOW WARNINGS [limit row_count].

return.desc: Returns the number of warnings from the last MySQL function, or 0 (zero) if no warnings occurred.

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection. If the link identifier is not specified, the last link opened by mysql_connect() is assumed. If no such link is found, it will try to create one as if mysql_connect() was called with no arguments. If no connection is found or established, an E_WARNING level error is generated.

funcs.name: mysql_get_client_info
funcs.desc: mysql_get_client_info() returns a string that represents the client library version.

return.desc: The MySQL client version.

funcs.name: mysql_get_host_info
funcs.desc: Describes the type of connection in use for the connection, including the server host name.

return.desc: Returns a string describing the type of MySQL connection in use for the connection or FALSE on failure.

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection. If the link identifier is not specified, the last link opened by mysql_connect() is assumed. If no such link is found, it will try to create one as if mysql_connect() was called with no arguments. If no connection is found or established, an E_WARNING level error is generated.

funcs.name: mysql_get_proto_info
funcs.desc: Retrieves the MySQL protocol.

return.desc: Returns the MySQL protocol on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection. If the link identifier is not specified, the last link opened by mysql_connect() is assumed. If no such link is found, it will try to create one as if mysql_connect() was called with no arguments. If no connection is found or established, an E_WARNING level error is generated.

funcs.name: mysql_get_server_info
funcs.desc: Retrieves the MySQL server version.

return.desc: Returns the MySQL server version on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection. If the link identifier is not specified, the last link opened by mysql_connect() is assumed. If no such link is found, it will try to create one as if mysql_connect() was called with no arguments. If no connection is found or established, an E_WARNING level error is generated.

funcs.name: mysql_info
funcs.desc: Returns detailed information about the last query.

return.desc: Returns information about the statement on success, or FALSE on failure. See the example below for which statements provide information, and what the returned value may look like. Statements that are not listed will return FALSE.

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection. If the link identifier is not specified, the last link opened by mysql_connect() is assumed. If no such link is found, it will try to create one as if mysql_connect() was called with no arguments. If no connection is found or established, an E_WARNING level error is generated.

funcs.name: mysql_insert_id
funcs.desc: Retrieves the ID generated for an AUTO_INCREMENT column by the previous query (usually INSERT).

return.desc: The ID generated for an AUTO_INCREMENT column by the previous query on success, 0 if the previous query does not generate an AUTO_INCREMENT value, or FALSE if no MySQL connection was established.

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection. If the link identifier is not specified, the last link opened by mysql_connect() is assumed. If no such link is found, it will try to create one as if mysql_connect() was called with no arguments. If no connection is found or established, an E_WARNING level error is generated.

funcs.name: mysql_stat
funcs.desc: mysql_stat() returns the current server status.

return.desc: Returns a string with the status for uptime, threads, queries, open tables, flush tables and queries per second. For a complete list of other status variables, you have to use the SHOW STATUS SQL command. If link_identifier is invalid, NULL is returned.

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection. If the link identifier is not specified, the last link opened by mysql_connect() is assumed. If no such link is found, it will try to create one as if mysql_connect() was called with no arguments. If no connection is found or established, an E_WARNING level error is generated.

funcs.name: mysql_thread_id
funcs.desc: Retrieves the current thread ID. If the connection is lost, and a reconnect with mysql_ping() is executed, the thread ID will change. This means only retrieve the thread ID when needed.

return.desc: The thread ID on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection. If the link identifier is not specified, the last link opened by mysql_connect() is assumed. If no such link is found, it will try to create one as if mysql_connect() was called with no arguments. If no connection is found or established, an E_WARNING level error is generated.

funcs.name: mysql_create_db
funcs.desc: mysql_create_db() attempts to create a new database on the server associated with the specified link identifier.

return.desc: Returns TRUE on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: db
args.desc: The name of the database being created.

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection. If the link identifier is not specified, the last link opened by mysql_connect() is assumed. If no such link is found, it will try to create one as if mysql_connect() was called with no arguments. If no connection is found or established, an E_WARNING level error is generated.

funcs.name: mysql_select_db
funcs.desc: Sets the current active database on the server that's associated with the specified link identifier. Every subsequent call to mysql_query() will be made on the active database.

return.desc: Returns TRUE on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: db
args.desc: The name of the database that is to be selected.

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection. If the link identifier is not specified, the last link opened by mysql_connect() is assumed. If no such link is found, it will try to create one as if mysql_connect() was called with no arguments. If no connection is found or established, an E_WARNING level error is generated.

funcs.name: mysql_drop_db
funcs.desc: mysql_drop_db() attempts to drop (remove) an entire database from the server associated with the specified link identifier. This function is deprecated, it is preferable to use mysql_query() to issue an sql DROP DATABASE statement instead.

return.desc: Returns TRUE on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: db
args.desc: The name of the database that will be deleted.

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection. If the link identifier is not specified, the last link opened by mysql_connect() is assumed. If no such link is found, it will try to create one as if mysql_connect() was called with no arguments. If no connection is found or established, an E_WARNING level error is generated.

funcs.name: mysql_affected_rows
funcs.desc: Get the number of affected rows by the last INSERT, UPDATE, REPLACE or DELETE query associated with link_identifier.

return.desc:
Returns the number of affected rows on success, and -1 if the last query failed.

If the last query was a DELETE query with no WHERE clause, all of the records will have been deleted from the table but this function will return zero with MySQL versions prior to 4.1.2.

When using UPDATE, MySQL will not update columns where the new value is the same as the old value. This creates the possibility that mysql_affected_rows() may not actually equal the number of rows matched, only the number of rows that were literally affected by the query.

The REPLACE statement first deletes the record with the same primary key and then inserts the new record. This function returns the number of deleted records plus the number of inserted records.

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection. If the link identifier is not specified, the last link opened by mysql_connect() is assumed. If no such link is found, it will try to create one as if mysql_connect() was called with no arguments. If no connection is found or established, an E_WARNING level error is generated.

funcs.name: mysql_set_timeout
funcs.desc: Sets query timeout for a connection.

args.name: query_timeout_ms
args.desc: How many milli-seconds to wait for an SQL query.

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: Which connection to set to. If absent, default or current connection will be applied to.

funcs.name: mysql_query
funcs.desc: mysql_query() sends a unique query (multiple queries are not supported) to the currently active database on the server that's associated with the specified link_identifier.

return.desc:
For SELECT, SHOW, DESCRIBE, EXPLAIN and other statements returning resultset, mysql_query() returns a resource on success, or FALSE on error.

For other type of SQL statements, INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE, DROP, etc, mysql_query() returns TRUE on success or FALSE on error.

The returned result resource should be passed to mysql_fetch_array(), and other functions for dealing with result tables, to access the returned data.

Use mysql_num_rows() to find out how many rows were returned for a SELECT statement or mysql_affected_rows() to find out how many rows were affected by a DELETE, INSERT, REPLACE, or UPDATE statement.

mysql_query() will also fail and return FALSE if the user does not have permission to access the table(s) referenced by the query.

args.name: query
args.desc:
An SQL query

The query string should not end with a semicolon. Data inside the query should be properly escaped.

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection. If the link identifier is not specified, the last link opened by mysql_connect() is assumed. If no such link is found, it will try to create one as if mysql_connect() was called with no arguments. If no connection is found or established, an E_WARNING level error is generated.

funcs.name: mysql_multi_query
funcs.desc: mysql_multi_query() executes one or more queries separated by a ; to the currently active database on the server that's associated with the specified link_identifier.

return.desc: This is a fb specific query so behaviour is a little random at the moment.

args.name: query
args.desc:
An SQL query

The query string should not end with a semicolon. Data inside the query should be properly escaped.

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection. If the link identifier is not specified, the last link opened by mysql_connect() is assumed. If no such link is found, it will try to create one as if mysql_connect() was called with no arguments. If no connection is found or established, an E_WARNING level error is generated.

funcs.name: mysql_next_result
funcs.desc: Used with mysql_multi_query() to move the result set on one.

return.desc: 0 - Query succeeded, more results coming.  -1 - Query succeeded, no more results coming.  >0 - query failed, value is error code.

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection. If the link identifier is not specified, the last link opened by mysql_connect() is assumed. If no such link is found, it will try to create one as if mysql_connect() was called with no arguments. If no connection is found or established, an E_WARNING level error is generated.

funcs.name: mysql_more_results
funcs.desc: Used with mysql_multi_query() to check if there are more result sets to be returned.

return.desc: True if there is at least one more item in the result set.

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection. If the link identifier is not specified, the last link opened by mysql_connect() is assumed. If no such link is found, it will try to create one as if mysql_connect() was called with no arguments. If no connection is found or established, an E_WARNING level error is generated.

funcs.name: mysql_fetch_result
funcs.desc: Used with mysql_multi_query() to return a mysql result for the current iterated query.

return.desc: Returns a resource or a boolean.

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection. If the link identifier is not specified, the last link opened by mysql_connect() is assumed. If no such link is found, it will try to create one as if mysql_connect() was called with no arguments. If no connection is found or established, an E_WARNING level error is generated.

funcs.name: mysql_unbuffered_query
funcs.desc: mysql_unbuffered_query() sends the SQL query query to MySQL without automatically fetching and buffering the result rows as mysql_query() does. This saves a considerable amount of memory with SQL queries that produce large result sets, and you can start working on the result set immediately after the first row has been retrieved as you don't have to wait until the complete SQL query has been performed. To use mysql_unbuffered_query() while multiple database connections are open, you must specify the optional parameter link_identifier to identify which connection you want to use.

return.desc:
For SELECT, SHOW, DESCRIBE or EXPLAIN statements, mysql_unbuffered_query() returns a resource on success, or FALSE on error.

For other type of SQL statements, UPDATE, DELETE, DROP, etc, mysql_unbuffered_query() returns TRUE on success or FALSE on error.

args.name: query
args.desc:
The SQL query to execute.

Data inside the query should be properly escaped.

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection. If the link identifier is not specified, the last link opened by mysql_connect() is assumed. If no such link is found, it will try to create one as if mysql_connect() was called with no arguments. If no connection is found or established, an E_WARNING level error is generated.

funcs.name: mysql_db_query
funcs.desc: mysql_db_query() selects a database, and executes a query on it. WarningThis function has been DEPRECATED as of PHP 5.3.0. Relying on this feature is highly discouraged.

return.desc: Returns a positive MySQL result resource to the query result, or FALSE on error. The function also returns TRUE/FALSE for INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE queries to indicate success/failure.

args.name: database
args.desc: The name of the database that will be selected.

args.name: query
args.desc:
The MySQL query.

Data inside the query should be properly escaped.

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection. If the link identifier is not specified, the last link opened by mysql_connect() is assumed. If no such link is found, it will try to create one as if mysql_connect() was called with no arguments. If no connection is found or established, an E_WARNING level error is generated.

funcs.name: mysql_list_dbs
funcs.desc: Returns a result pointer containing the databases available from the current mysql daemon.

return.desc: Returns a result pointer resource on success, or FALSE on failure. Use the mysql_tablename() function to traverse this result pointer, or any function for result tables, such as mysql_fetch_array().

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection. If the link identifier is not specified, the last link opened by mysql_connect() is assumed. If no such link is found, it will try to create one as if mysql_connect() was called with no arguments. If no connection is found or established, an E_WARNING level error is generated.

funcs.name: mysql_list_tables
funcs.desc:
Retrieves a list of table names from a MySQL database.

This function is deprecated. It is preferable to use mysql_query() to issue an SQL SHOW TABLES [FROM db_name] [LIKE 'pattern'] statement instead.

return.desc:
A result pointer resource on success or FALSE on failure.

Use the mysql_tablename() function to traverse this result pointer, or any function for result tables, such as mysql_fetch_array().

args.name: database
args.desc: The name of the database

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection. If the link identifier is not specified, the last link opened by mysql_connect() is assumed. If no such link is found, it will try to create one as if mysql_connect() was called with no arguments. If no connection is found or established, an E_WARNING level error is generated.

funcs.name: mysql_list_fields
funcs.desc:
Retrieves information about the given table name.

This function is deprecated. It is preferable to use mysql_query() to issue an SQL SHOW COLUMNS FROM table [LIKE 'name'] statement instead.

return.desc:
A result pointer resource on success, or FALSE on failure.

The returned result can be used with mysql_field_flags(), mysql_field_len(), mysql_field_name() and mysql_field_type().

args.name: database_name
args.desc: The name of the database that's being queried.

args.name: table_name
args.desc: The name of the table that's being queried.

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection. If the link identifier is not specified, the last link opened by mysql_connect() is assumed. If no such link is found, it will try to create one as if mysql_connect() was called with no arguments. If no connection is found or established, an E_WARNING level error is generated.

funcs.name: mysql_list_processes
funcs.desc: Retrieves the current MySQL server threads.

return.desc: A result pointer resource on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: link_identifier
args.desc: The MySQL connection. If the link identifier is not specified, the last link opened by mysql_connect() is assumed. If no such link is found, it will try to create one as if mysql_connect() was called with no arguments. If no connection is found or established, an E_WARNING level error is generated.

funcs.name: mysql_db_name
funcs.desc: Retrieve the database name from a call to mysql_list_dbs().

return.desc: Returns the database name on success, and FALSE on failure. If FALSE is returned, use mysql_error() to determine the nature of the error.

args.name: result
args.desc: The result pointer from a call to mysql_list_dbs().

args.name: row
args.desc: The index into the result set.

args.name: field
args.desc: The field name.

funcs.name: mysql_tablename
funcs.desc:
Retrieves the table name from a result.

This function is deprecated. It is preferable to use mysql_query() to issue an SQL SHOW TABLES [FROM db_name] [LIKE 'pattern'] statement instead.

return.desc:
The name of the table on success or FALSE on failure.

Use the mysql_tablename() function to traverse this result pointer, or any function for result tables, such as mysql_fetch_array().

args.name: result
args.desc: A result pointer resource that's returned from mysql_list_tables().

args.name: i
args.desc: The integer index (row/table number)

funcs.name: mysql_num_fields
funcs.desc: Retrieves the number of fields from a query.

return.desc: Returns the number of fields in the result set resource on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: result
args.desc: resource that is being evaluated. This result comes from a call to mysql_query().

funcs.name: mysql_num_rows
funcs.desc: Retrieves the number of rows from a result set. This command is only valid for statements like SELECT or SHOW that return an actual result set. To retrieve the number of rows affected by a INSERT, UPDATE, REPLACE or DELETE query, use mysql_affected_rows().

return.desc: The number of rows in a result set on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: result
args.desc: resource that is being evaluated. This result comes from a call to mysql_query().

funcs.name: mysql_free_result
funcs.desc:
mysql_free_result() will free all memory associated with the result identifier result.

mysql_free_result() only needs to be called if you are concerned about how much memory is being used for queries that return large result sets. All associated result memory is automatically freed at the end of the script's execution.

return.desc:
Returns TRUE on success or FALSE on failure.

If a non-resource is used for the result, an error of level E_WARNING will be emitted. It's worth noting that mysql_query() only returns a resource for SELECT, SHOW, EXPLAIN, and DESCRIBE queries.

args.name: result
args.desc: resource that is being evaluated. This result comes from a call to mysql_query().

funcs.name: mysql_data_seek
funcs.desc:
mysql_data_seek() moves the internal row pointer of the MySQL result associated with the specified result identifier to point to the specified row number. The next call to a MySQL fetch function, such as mysql_fetch_assoc(), would return that row.

row_number starts at 0. The row_number should be a value in the range from 0 to mysql_num_rows() - 1. However if the result set is empty (mysql_num_rows() == 0), a seek to 0 will fail with a E_WARNING and mysql_data_seek() will return FALSE.

return.desc: Returns TRUE on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: result
args.desc: resource that is being evaluated. This result comes from a call to mysql_query().

args.name: row
args.desc: The desired row number of the new result pointer.

funcs.name: mysql_fetch_row
funcs.desc: Returns a numerical array that corresponds to the fetched row and moves the internal data pointer ahead.

return.desc:
Returns an numerical array of strings that corresponds to the fetched row, or FALSE if there are no more rows.

mysql_fetch_row() fetches one row of data from the result associated with the specified result identifier. The row is returned as an array. Each result column is stored in an array offset, starting at offset 0.

args.name: result
args.desc: resource that is being evaluated. This result comes from a call to mysql_query().

funcs.name: mysql_fetch_assoc
funcs.desc: Returns an associative array that corresponds to the fetched row and moves the internal data pointer ahead. mysql_fetch_assoc() is equivalent to calling mysql_fetch_array() with MYSQL_ASSOC for the optional second parameter. It only returns an associative array.

return.desc:
Returns an associative array of strings that corresponds to the fetched row, or FALSE if there are no more rows.

If two or more columns of the result have the same field names, the last column will take precedence. To access the other column(s) of the same name, you either need to access the result with numeric indices by using mysql_fetch_row() or add alias names. See the example at the mysql_fetch_array() description about aliases.

args.name: result
args.desc: resource that is being evaluated. This result comes from a call to mysql_query().

funcs.name: mysql_fetch_array
funcs.desc: Returns an array that corresponds to the fetched row and moves the internal data pointer ahead.

return.desc:
Returns an array of strings that corresponds to the fetched row, or FALSE if there are no more rows. The type of returned array depends on how result_type is defined. By using MYSQL_BOTH (default), you'll get an array with both associative and number indices. Using MYSQL_ASSOC, you only get associative indices (as mysql_fetch_assoc() works), using MYSQL_NUM, you only get number indices (as mysql_fetch_row() works).

If two or more columns of the result have the same field names, the last column will take precedence. To access the other column(s) of the same name, you must use the numeric index of the column or make an alias for the column. For aliased columns, you cannot access the contents with the original column name.

args.name: result
args.desc: resource that is being evaluated. This result comes from a call to mysql_query().

args.name: result_type
args.desc: The type of array that is to be fetched. It's a constant and can take the following values: MYSQL_ASSOC, MYSQL_NUM, and MYSQL_BOTH.

funcs.name: mysql_fetch_lengths
funcs.desc:
Returns an array that corresponds to the lengths of each field in the last row fetched by MySQL.

mysql_fetch_lengths() stores the lengths of each result column in the last row returned by mysql_fetch_row(), mysql_fetch_assoc(), mysql_fetch_array(), and mysql_fetch_object() in an array, starting at offset 0.

return.desc: An array of lengths on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: result
args.desc: resource that is being evaluated. This result comes from a call to mysql_query().

funcs.name: mysql_fetch_object
funcs.desc: Returns an object with properties that correspond to the fetched row and moves the internal data pointer ahead.

return.desc: Returns an object with string properties that correspond to the fetched row, or FALSE if there are no more rows.

args.name: result
args.desc: resource that is being evaluated. This result comes from a call to mysql_query().

args.name: class_name
args.desc: The name of the class to instantiate, set the properties of and return. If not specified, a stdClass object is returned.

args.name: params
args.desc: An optional array of parameters to pass to the constructor for class_name objects.

funcs.name: mysql_result
funcs.desc:
Retrieves the contents of one cell from a MySQL result set.

When working on large result sets, you should consider using one of the functions that fetch an entire row (specified below). As these functions return the contents of multiple cells in one function call, they're MUCH quicker than mysql_result(). Also, note that specifying a numeric offset for the field argument is much quicker than specifying a fieldname or tablename.fieldname argument.

return.desc: The contents of one cell from a MySQL result set on success, or FALSE on failure.

args.name: result
args.desc: resource that is being evaluated. This result comes from a call to mysql_query().

args.name: row
args.desc: The row number from the result that's being retrieved. Row numbers start at 0.

args.name: field
args.desc:
The name or offset of the field being retrieved.

It can be the field's offset, the field's name, or the field's table dot field name (tablename.fieldname). If the column name has been aliased ('select foo as bar from...'), use the alias instead of the column name. If undefined, the first field is retrieved.

funcs.name: mysql_fetch_field
funcs.desc: Returns an object containing field information. This function can be used to obtain information about fields in the provided query result.

return.desc:
Returns an object containing field information. The properties of the object are:

name - column name table - name of the table the column belongs to max_length - maximum length of the column not_null - 1 if the column cannot be NULL primary_key - 1 if the column is a primary key unique_key - 1 if the column is a unique key multiple_key - 1 if the column is a non-unique key numeric - 1 if the column is numeric blob - 1 if the column is a BLOB type - the type of the column unsigned - 1 if the column is unsigned zerofill - 1 if the column is zero-filled

args.name: result
args.desc: resource that is being evaluated. This result comes from a call to mysql_query().

args.name: field
args.desc: The numerical field offset. If the field offset is not specified, the next field that was not yet retrieved by this function is retrieved. The field_offset starts at 0.

funcs.name: mysql_field_seek
funcs.desc: Seeks to the specified field offset. If the next call to mysql_fetch_field() doesn't include a field offset, the field offset specified in mysql_field_seek() will be returned.

return.desc: Returns TRUE on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: result
args.desc: resource that is being evaluated. This result comes from a call to mysql_query().

args.name: field
args.desc: The numerical field offset. The field_offset starts at 0. If field_offset does not exist, an error of level E_WARNING is also issued.

funcs.name: mysql_field_name
funcs.desc: mysql_field_name() returns the name of the specified field index.

return.desc: The name of the specified field index on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: result
args.desc: resource that is being evaluated. This result comes from a call to mysql_query().

args.name: field
args.desc: The numerical field offset. The field_offset starts at 0. If field_offset does not exist, an error of level E_WARNING is also issued.

funcs.name: mysql_field_table
funcs.desc: Returns the name of the table that the specified field is in.

return.desc: The name of the table on success.

args.name: result
args.desc: resource that is being evaluated. This result comes from a call to mysql_query().

args.name: field
args.desc: The numerical field offset. The field_offset starts at 0. If field_offset does not exist, an error of level E_WARNING is also issued.

funcs.name: mysql_field_len
funcs.desc: mysql_field_len() returns the length of the specified field.

return.desc: The length of the specified field index on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: result
args.desc: resource that is being evaluated. This result comes from a call to mysql_query().

args.name: field
args.desc: The numerical field offset. The field_offset starts at 0. If field_offset does not exist, an error of level E_WARNING is also issued.

funcs.name: mysql_field_type
funcs.desc: mysql_field_type() is similar to the mysql_field_name() function. The arguments are identical, but the field type is returned instead.

return.desc: The returned field type will be one of "int", "real", "string", "blob", and others as detailed in the MySQL documentation.

args.name: result
args.desc: resource that is being evaluated. This result comes from a call to mysql_query().

args.name: field
args.desc: The numerical field offset. The field_offset starts at 0. If field_offset does not exist, an error of level E_WARNING is also issued.

funcs.name: mysql_field_flags
funcs.desc: mysql_field_flags() returns the field flags of the specified field. The flags are reported as a single word per flag separated by a single space, so that you can split the returned value using explode().

return.desc:
Returns a string of flags associated with the result or FALSE on failure.

The following flags are reported, if your version of MySQL is current enough to support them: "not_null", "primary_key", "unique_key", "multiple_key", "blob", "unsigned", "zerofill", "binary", "enum", "auto_increment" and "timestamp".

args.name: result
args.desc: resource that is being evaluated. This result comes from a call to mysql_query().

args.name: field
args.desc: The numerical field offset. The field_offset starts at 0. If field_offset does not exist, an error of level E_WARNING is also issued.
